title: 110_s3571
content: The "Health Impact Assessments Act of 2008" or the "HIA Act of 2008" requires studies by the Government Accountability Office to identify best practices for assessing the planning and impact of land use, building design, and social policy on community health. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on best practices for using health impact assessments to promote health and reduce disparities through social policy, land use, and public projects. A report on the study's results must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to review the health consequences of Federal policies and programs, and how to incorporate health impact assessments for projects involving Federal funding or work. A report on the study's results must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The United States must submit a report to Congress detailing the results of a study on the health consequences of Federal policies and programs, including how to incorporate health impact assessments for projects with Federal funding or work. SEC. 3. NATIONAL DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will award a grant to an institution of higher education to provide technical assistance, grants, and training on health impact assessments for community planning and policy making. The Center awarded grants for health impact assessments and community design policy decisions. Consultation with national organizations is required. Eligible entities can receive grants for demonstration projects on health impact assessments. Eligible entities for grants include State and local government health departments and planning departments. Recipients must consult with other eligible entities. Authorization of appropriations is specified for fiscal years 2009-2013. Authorization of appropriations for eligible entities for grants includes $4,000,000 for fiscal year 2009 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2010-2011. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will expand activities to improve public health and reduce disparities by promoting health impact assessments in various areas. This includes developing guidance for assessing public participation and health effects of land use, housing, transportation policies, and social decisions. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009, with additional funding for fiscal years 2010-2013. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "built environment" refers to all buildings, spaces, and products created or modified by individuals, including homes, schools, workplaces, parks, transportation systems, electric transmission lines, waste disposal sites, and land-use planning. The term "health impact assessment" involves analyzing the effects of a policy, program, or project on the health of a population. The term "health impact assessment" involves evaluating the potential health effects of a project or policy within the population and recommending actions to manage those effects. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
